title: Service D3 Disk Space Exhaustion Preventing Request Processing

symptoms.user_facing: 33% of B path requests failing with 500 internal server errors
monitoring_alerts: Service D3 unable to write temp files
Service D3 application crashes due to disk write failures

root_cause.primary: Service D3 disk space exhausted by accumulated temporary cache files not being cleaned
root_cause.secondary: Cache cleanup cron job disabled during maintenance and never re-enabled

analysis_steps: 1. 33% of B requests failing, isolated to D3 instance
2. D3 system metrics show 100% disk utilization
3. D3 application logs show 'No space left on device' errors
4. Investigation reveals /tmp directory with 25GB of cache files
5. Cache files dated back 2 weeks, not being cleaned up
6. Found disabled cleanup cron job in system maintenance logs
7. Manual cleanup restored service functionality
resolution: Manually cleaned disk space, re-enabled cache cleanup cron job, added disk monitoring
lessons_learned: Disk space monitoring with proactive alerts needed
Maintenance procedures must include verification checklists
Implement automated cleanup with fallback procedures

title: Service B Memory Pressure Causing Frequent Garbage Collection

symptoms.user_facing: B path requests experiencing variable latency spikes (200ms to 2s)
monitoring_alerts: Service B JVM GC time > 15% of total time
Service B response time variance high

root_cause.primary: Service B JVM heap size insufficient for increased load, causing frequent full GC cycles
root_cause.secondary: Memory leak in request context objects not being garbage collected promptly

analysis_steps: 1. B path showing inconsistent response times with periodic spikes
2. JVM monitoring shows frequent full GC cycles (every 30 seconds)
3. Heap analysis reveals 85-95% utilization before each GC
4. GC logs show old generation collection taking 800ms-1.2s
5. Memory profiling identifies request context objects accumulating
6. Found ThreadLocal variables not being cleared after requests
7. Combination of insufficient heap + memory leak causing pressure
resolution: Increased B service heap size from 2GB to 4GB, fixed ThreadLocal cleanup
lessons_learned: JVM heap sizing should account for peak load scenarios
Regular memory profiling to identify accumulation patterns
ThreadLocal usage requires explicit cleanup procedures

title: Service F External API Dependency Timeout Cascade

symptoms.user_facing: All C path requests timing out after 30 seconds
monitoring_alerts: Service F external API timeout rate > 50%
Service F request queue backing up

root_cause.primary: External payment API provider experiencing outage causing F service timeouts
root_cause.secondary: Service F lacks circuit breaker pattern, continuing to call failing API

analysis_steps: 1. All C path requests failing with timeout errors
2. Service C logs show F taking > 30s to respond
3. Service F logs reveal external payment API timeouts
4. External API provider status page confirms ongoing outage
5. F service continuing to retry failed API calls without backoff
6. Request queue in F backing up, consuming all threads
7. No fallback mechanism or circuit breaker implemented
resolution: Implemented temporary circuit breaker, enabled fallback mode, coordinated with API provider
lessons_learned: Circuit breaker pattern essential for external dependencies
Implement graceful degradation for non-critical external calls
Monitor external dependency health and SLA compliance

title: Network Partition Between Service C and F Data Centers

symptoms.user_facing: Complete failure of C path requests - 100% error rate
monitoring_alerts: Service C cannot reach Service F
Network connectivity lost between DC-East and DC-West
Service F health checks failing from C's perspective

root_cause.primary: Network partition caused by ISP backbone fiber cut between data centers
root_cause.secondary: No cross-datacenter redundancy or failover mechanism implemented

analysis_steps: 1. Complete failure of all C path requests starting 16:30
2. Service C logs show 'Connection refused' to all F endpoints
3. Service F appears healthy from its own monitoring
4. Network team confirms connectivity loss between DC-East (C) and DC-West (F)
5. ISP reports fiber cut affecting backbone connection
6. No alternative network paths available
7. Services not designed for cross-DC failures
resolution: ISP repaired fiber connection, implemented temporary traffic rerouting
lessons_learned: Network partition testing should be part of disaster recovery
